channel.title: Call Quality on 0x000216
channel.description: Recent content in Call Quality on 0x000216

item.title: T-1 Digital Telephone Lines
item.description: Businesses with multiple phone lines might be leaving money on the table if they haven’t explored T-1 digital phone lines. Even businesses already using T1 service might be unaware of potential savings from newer options. Digital telephony emerged in the 1950s as phone companies sought efficient ways to handle large call volumes. Analog phone lines carried a single conversation per wire pair. While analog multiplexing (carrier telephony) allowed multiple calls on a single wire pair, it suffered from quality issues over long distances.

item.title: SIP over MPLS for Enterprise VoIP
item.description: Small businesses often utilize SIP Trunking to reduce their monthly telecommunication expenses by combining their telephone and internet broadband services onto a single line. This technology also benefits large corporations and call centers requiring numerous external phone lines and possessing converged voice and data LANs. However, organizations with multiple locations may find SIP over MPLS a more suitable solution. Deploying SIP over MPLS might be the optimal choice if your organization utilizes an MPLS network for interoffice data sharing.

item.title: Achieving Call Quality Momentum With Cloud Communications
item.description: By: John Shepler Are you frustrated by your outdated in-house phone system? Perhaps you’ve had a negative experience with VoIP, finding it unreliable and offering poor call quality. It might be time to consider a modern cloud communication solution, such as one from Momentum. If you’re unfamiliar with IP-based voice communication, you might not be aware of potential issues that can impact network voice systems, or the solutions that are simply inadequate.

item.title: T1 Voice Options for Call Quality
item.description: For businesses reliant on phone communication, exceptional call quality is non-negotiable. This means clear, natural-sounding voices with minimal disruptions like dropped calls, echoes, or choppy audio. If this resonates, T1 voice service might be your solution. T1 lines are a natural fit for business phone systems as they were intentionally designed for this purpose. T-Carrier technology, including T1 (1.5 Mbps) and T3 (45 Mbps), was initially developed for use by phone companies.
